questions.text:
Two days after admission to the hospital for treatment of acute myelogenous leukemia, a 35-year-old man develops nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and muscle cramps. He has a history of diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years and reports occasionally using marijuana. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.1°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
16,000/mm3



Hemoglobin
13.4 g/dL


Platelet count
180,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

5.9 mEq/L


Cl-

101 mEq/L


HCO3-

24 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
27 mg/dL


Uric acid
11.2 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL


Glucose
134 mg/dL


Ca2+

6.8 mg/dL


Mg2+

1.8 mg/dL


Phosphorus
8.9 mg/dL


Which of the following is most likely to have been effective in preventing this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine alkalinization with the use of acetazolamide or sodium bicarbonate was previously recommended as a measure to increase uric acid solubility and, consequently, decrease the risk of TLS. However, this intervention is no longer performed routinely because of its unproven effectiveness and potential adverse effects.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used as adjunctive treatment in some cases of hematologic malignancies (e.g., lymphoma), but they do not have a role in the treatment of TLS.

C) INCORRECT:

Rasburicase, a urate oxidase recombinant, is a drug that helps degrade uric acid, catalyzing it to a more soluble compound (allantoin). Administering rasburicase is effective as an adjunctive measure for the prevention of TLS, but it is not the most effective measure.

D) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol is a hypouricemic drug that is used as an adjunctive measure for the prevention of urate nephropathy, which usually can occur as a sequela of TLS. Although this drug is useful in the management of this complication because it decreases uric acid formation, it is not the most effective preventive measure for TLS.

E) CORRECT:

Intravenous hydration is recommended for all patients at risk of developing TLS. Patients receiving cytotoxic treatment for hematological malignancies with high cell turnover (e.g., leukemias or lymphomas) are especially at risk of developing TLS as a result of rapid cell lysis. The condition is characterized by the massive release of intracellular components, such as potassium, phosphate, and uric acid, into the blood, which can cause acute urate nephropathy leading to acute kidney failure and death. Adequate hydration prior to receiving chemotherapy helps minimize kidney injury and symptoms.

Electrolyte abnormalities in TLS can lead to seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death.
Image Description:

Tumor lysis syndrome results from the rapid destruction of tumor cells and subsequent massive release of intracellular components. It occurs most commonly in patients with hematologic malignancies (e.g., ALL, AML, or NHL) at the beginning of cytotoxic treatment, but may also occur spontaneously. The accumulation of uric acid crystals can cause acute kidney injury, and the electrolyte imbalances can have life-threatening consequences such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.
questions.hint: This patient who has recently begun chemotherapy for hematologic malignancy presents with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and muscle cramps. In combination with the laboratory findings (↑ potassium, ↑ urea nitrogen, ↑ uric acid, ↑ phosphorus, ↓ calcium), his presentation indicates tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and weakness for the past 5 days. During this period, she has had a headache that worsens when she leans forward or lies down. Her arms and face have appeared swollen over the past 2 weeks. She has a history of hypertension and invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent radical amputation of the left breast followed by radiation therapy 4 years ago. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Current medications include aspirin, hydrochlorothiazide, and tamoxifen. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 98/56 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention, a mastectomy scar over the left thorax, and engorged veins on the anterior chest wall. There is no axillary or cervical lymphadenopathy. There is 1+ pitting edema in both arms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While Hodgkin lymphomas frequently manifest with mediastinal lymphadenopathy, compression of the SVC resulting in SVC syndrome is rare. Non-Hodgkin lymphomas, on the other hand, are responsible for the majority of cases of SVC syndrome in young patients. This patient lacks any typical symptoms of lymphoma (painless lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or B symptoms), which makes a malignant lymphoma unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) usually manifests with a blood-tinged mucopurulent cough, fever, chills, and night sweats and is typically seen in individuals with a history of travel to an endemic region or exposure to TB. Although pulmonary TB may cause sclerosing mediastinitis, which can manifest similarly to SVC syndrome, the absence of other more common findings associated with TB or a history of TB exposure makes this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of breast cancer, chronic smoking, and tamoxifen therapy increases the risk of a hypercoagulable state and the development of a pulmonary embolism (PE). PE may cause right heart failure (i.e., jugular venous distension, hypotension, tachycardia) but not selective facial and upper limb edema. In addition, and in contrast to this patient's features, PE manifests with respiratory distress, cough, and rales on pulmonary auscultation.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is a predisposing factor for the development of constrictive pericarditis, which may be the underlying cause of this patient's jugular venous distension and peripheral edema. However, patients with constrictive pericarditis typically have a thickened myocardium and a pericardial knock on auscultation, which is not heard here. Additionally, the peripheral edema in constrictive pericarditis involves both the upper and lower extremities; the presence of a selective facial and upper limb edema in this patient suggests another etiology.

E) CORRECT:

SVC syndrome is most commonly caused by lung cancer (usually small cell lung cancer or squamous cell carcinoma) or non-Hodgkin lymphoma (particularly in younger patients). This patient's history of chronic smoking is a risk factor for lung cancer. Compression of the SVC by a tumor impairs the venous backflow to the right atrium, resulting in venous congestion in the head, neck, and upper extremities. Other nonmalignant causes of SVC syndrome include mediastinal fibrosis, tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, or thrombosis of the SVC due to the placement of a central venous device. A CT scan of the chest should be obtained in this patient to evaluate for malignancy.
Image Description:

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is caused by obstruction of the SVC (e.g., due to malignancy or intraluminal thrombosis), resulting in impaired blood flow from the SVC into the right atrium. As a consequence, drainage occurs increasingly into the inferior vena cava via collateral veins, resulting in a prominent venous patterning on the upper body. Venous congestion proximally to the obstruction results in edema of the upper extremities, neck, and face.

SVC syndrome can become life-threatening if cerebral edema (leading to increased intracranial pressure) or laryngeal edema develop.

F) INCORRECT:

Nephrotic syndrome causes renal filtration dysfunction and is characterized by marked edema, weight gain, hypertension, and a hypercoagulable state. This patient has a selective facial and upper limb edema, which is not characteristic of the edema pattern seen in nephrotic syndrome (initially a periorbital and later general edema). Additionally, nephrotic syndrome does not explain this patient's JVD, tachycardia, and hypotension.
questions.hint: Headache that worsens when leaning forward, engorged veins over the anterior chest, and swelling limited to the head, neck, and upper extremities are consistent with superior vena cava syndrome (SVC syndrome).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with chronic myelogenous leukemia comes to the physician because of severe pain and swelling in both knees for the past day. He finished a cycle of chemotherapy 1 week ago. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F). Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of both knees and the base of his left big toe. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
13,000/mm3



Serum



Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL


Calcium
8.2 mg/dL


Phosphorus
7.2 mg/dL


Arthrocentesis of the involved joints is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulocytes with cytoplasmic inclusion bodies, also known as ragocytes, would be consistent with autoimmune-related arthropathies, including rheumatoid arthritis and SLE. They are not seen in tumor lysis syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs when there is widespread lysis of cancer cells (e.g., from chemotherapy), resulting in the release of large amounts of intracellular components such as nucleic acid, which is further broken down to monosodium urate (uric acid). The subsequent hyperuricemia can lead to the precipitation of monosodium urate crystals in the renal tubules and joints, causing acute kidney injury and triggering gout, as seen in this patient. Arthrocentesis of the involved joints would reveal needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals.
Image Description:

Tumor lysis syndrome results from the rapid destruction of tumor cells and subsequent massive release of intracellular components. It occurs most commonly in patients with hematologic malignancies (e.g., ALL, AML, or NHL) at the beginning of cytotoxic treatment, but may also occur spontaneously. The accumulation of uric acid crystals can cause acute kidney injury, and the electrolyte imbalances can have life-threatening consequences such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals within the joint space is the pathomechanism of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease. Arthritis in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease commonly affects only one joint (usually the knee), and arthroscopy typically reveals rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. The disease is usually idiopathic, but can be caused by hemochromatosis, hyperparathyroidism, or trauma to the joint. Calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition is not a sequela of tumor lysis syndrome.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals with typical rhomboid shapes. They appear blue when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer and yellow when their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer (positive birefringence). The overall birefringence of CPP crystals is weak compared to monosodium urate crystals.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium phosphate crystals are non-birefringent, globular crystals associated with degenerative joint diseases, such as osteoarthritis. Patients with this condition have chronic joint disease of the weight-bearing joints and morning stiffness lasting less than 30 minutes. While tumor lysis syndrome can lead to deposition of calcium phosphate crystals in the kidneys (predisposing to acute kidney injury), deposition of these crystals in the joints is not a sequela of tumor lysis syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative diplococci in the synovial fluid culture would be concerning for gonococcal arthritis, a type of oligoarthritis commonly seen in sexually active adults. It presents either as monoarthritis (e.g., of the knee), or as polyarthralgia with dermatitis and tenosynovitis. Tumor lysis syndrome does not predispose to gonococcal arthritis.

F) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive cocci in clusters in the joint space would be consistent with septic arthritis due to Staphylococcus aureus. Patients typically present with acute monoarticular joint pain, swelling, and fever. Risk factors include prosthetic joints, skin infection, or IV drug abuse. Tumor lysis syndrome does not predispose to septic arthritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with elevated creatinine, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia one week after chemotherapy. This is consistent with tumor lysis syndrome.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy with Burkitt lymphoma is brought to the emergency department because of nausea, vomiting, flank pain, and dark urine for 1 day. Two days ago, he began induction chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisolone, and doxorubicin. Urinalysis shows 3+ blood and the findings in the photograph. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent a recurrence of this patient's symptoms has which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Free radical neutralization is the mechanism of action of amifostine. Free radical scavengers such as amifostine are used to prevent nephrotoxicity in patients receiving platinum-based alkylating agents (e.g., cisplatin) but are not used to treat or prevent urate nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of DNA gyrase is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), which are used to treat urinary tract infections such as pyelonephritis. Although pyelonephritis can manifest with flank pain, nausea, and hematuria, the presence of urate crystals indicates a different condition.

C) CORRECT:

The use of recombinant uricase and xanthine oxidase inhibitors can prevent urate nephropathy caused by tumor lysis syndrome. Recombinant uricase (e.g., rasburicase, pegloticase) oxidizes urate to allantoin, which is highly water-soluble and excreted in the urine without forming stones. Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol, febuxostat) decrease the serum concentration and urinary excretion of urate by blocking the formation of urate from xanthine and hypoxanthine.
Image Description:

Tumor lysis syndrome results from the rapid destruction of tumor cells and subsequent massive release of intracellular components. It occurs most commonly in patients with hematologic malignancies (e.g., ALL, AML, or NHL) at the beginning of cytotoxic treatment, but may also occur spontaneously. The accumulation of uric acid crystals can cause acute kidney injury, and the electrolyte imbalances can have life-threatening consequences such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of urate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule is the mechanism of action of probenecid, which is used to prevent chronic gout. However, since probenecid is a uricosuric drug, it would increase rather than decrease the risk of urate nephropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

The consumption of betaine or cranberry juice acidifies the urine, helping to prevent the formation of calcium phosphate and struvite stones, which precipitate in an alkaline environment. Calcium phosphate crystals are wedge- or rosette-shaped and struvite crystals are hexagonal. Uric acid stones precipitate in an acidic environment and urine acidification would increase rather than decrease the risk of urate nephropathy.
questions.hint: Hematuria and rhomboid crystals in the urine are consistent with urate nephropathy, which can occur after chemotherapy as a consequence of hyperuricemia in tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).

questions.text: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of dyspnea, chest pain, dry cough, painful swallowing, and a feeling of fullness in his head. The symptoms were initially mild but have progressively worsened. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with esomeprazole. He does not smoke cigarettes. His pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 95/66 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and redness of the face and neck. There is distention of the superficial veins of his neck and upper thorax. Chest x-rays show a widened mediastinum and unremarkable lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pancoast tumors can manifest with progressive superior vena cava obstruction. However, Pancoast tumors are classically associated with shoulder pain, Horner syndrome, and a positive smoking history, none of which are present in this case. Moreover, the absence of a soft tissue mass or other abnormality in the apices of the right lung field makes this diagnosis even less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal adenocarcinoma manifests with dysphagia and is more common in patients with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), such as this patient. However, esophageal cancer is an exceptionally rare cause of superior vena cava syndrome, making a different etiology much more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade causes dyspnea, chest discomfort, and neck vein distention, all of which are seen in this patient. Other important clinical findings include muffled heart sounds, pulsus paradoxus, and heart failure, which can lead to cardiogenic shock in severe cases. This patient's subacute symptom onset and dysphagia would not be expected in the case of cardiac tamponade. Moreover, radiographs of the chest would most often show cardiomegaly rather than a widened mediastinum.

D) INCORRECT:

A descending thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) originates distal to the left subclavian artery and is typically asymptomatic, with the diagnosis being made incidentally. TAA can manifest in rare cases with superior vena cava syndrome, in which case chest x-ray would show a widened mediastinum. However, patients with symptomatic TAA most often present acutely with a “tearing” or “ripping” chest pain that radiates to the back between the scapulae, as well as hemodynamic instability marked by profound hypotension, tachycardia, and signs of systemic shock (e.g., pallor, cool extremities, and loss of peripheral pulses). It would also be uncommon for a TAA to compress the superior vena cava without also compressing the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, which would cause hoarseness.

E) CORRECT:

Mediastinal lymphoma is one of the classic causes of superior vena cava syndrome (SVC syndrome). Neoplastic growth of the anterior and middle mediastinal lymph nodes causes these structures to expand and impinge on the surrounding anatomy (e.g., SVC and esophagus). The superior vena cava is directly adjacent to these chains of lymph nodes, and even partial obstruction of the SVC can manifest clinically. Coupled with the absence of risk factors for lung cancer or evidence of a soft tissue mass in the apices (which is seen in cases of Pancoast tumor), clinical evidence of impingement on other mediastinal structures (e.g., dysphagia from esophageal impingement) and the radiographic finding of a widened mediastinum make mediastinal lymphoma the most likely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is caused by obstruction of the SVC (e.g., due to malignancy or intraluminal thrombosis), resulting in impaired blood flow from the SVC into the right atrium. As a consequence, drainage occurs increasingly into the inferior vena cava via collateral veins, resulting in a prominent venous patterning on the upper body. Venous congestion proximally to the obstruction results in edema of the upper extremities, neck, and face.

SVC syndrome can become life-threatening if cerebral edema (leading to increased intracranial pressure) or laryngeal edema develop.
questions.hint: Cervicofacial swelling and venous distention, as well as a subacute onset and worsening of dyspnea, chest pain, cough, dysphagia, and a feeling of fullness in the head, are all consistent with superior vena cava syndrome.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man is hospitalized with acute dyspnea, dry cough, subjectively reported fevers, and confusion.
He has an oxygen saturation of 81% while he is breathing ambient air, a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, a temperature of 38.0°C, a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 105/72 mm Hg. His pulmonary examination is notable for scattered crackles, and he also exhibits splenomegaly and pallor.
Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 321,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 95% myeloblasts and a hemoglobin level of 8.1 g/dL (13.5–17.5).
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated.
Which one of the following treatments should be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Heparin and thrombolytics would not be indicated in this case, as pulmonary embolus is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Diuretics are not beneficial and could cause harm, as they would increase viscosity and might further occlude the pulmonary vessels.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with acute leukemia and elevated blast counts can develop leukostasis, a condition in which the pulmonary blood vessels become occluded and infiltrated by tumor cells. This can result in significant hypoxemia, dyspnea, and low-grade fevers. A chest radiograph will often be clear, as the abnormality is in the vessels. The central nervous system may also be affected, resulting in neurologic symptoms such as confusion.

The appropriate treatment for leukostasis is induction chemotherapy. In some settings, leukapheresis may be used if chemotherapy is delayed.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for pulmonary leukostasis due to acute myeloid leukemia is induction chemotherapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Heparin and thrombolytics would not be indicated in this case, as pulmonary embolus is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids have no appropriate role in the setting of leukostasis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is hospitalized with a 3-week history of progressive dyspnea on exertion, intermittent fevers, night sweats, and cough. She says she has no headaches or vision changes.
On physical examination, her temperature is 38°C, her blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg, her heart rate is 104 beats per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 95% on 2 liters of supplemental oxygen administered by nasal cannula. She has facial edema and venous distention on her chest wall. She does not have stridor. She has no mental status changes; her neurologic examination is within normal limits.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11.0
12.0–16.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4400
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
170,000
150,000–350,000


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.4
0.3–1.0


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.1
0.6–1.1


Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
634
100–190


CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis reveals a 15-cm by 10-cm mediastinal mass, with moderate compression of the superior vena cava and no evidence of tracheal compression or venous thrombosis. There are no pleural or pericardial effusions. There are no other sites of lymphadenopathy.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Place an endovascular stent in the superior vena cava
Order a biopsy of the mediastinal mass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has compression of the superior vena cava, there is no evidence of thrombosis, so thrombolytic therapy or heparin are not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

There is a limited role for placing an endovascular stent in the superior vena cava if the patient does not have severe respiratory compromise or neurologic changes.

C) INCORRECT:

An accurate histologic diagnosis is essential prior to starting therapy, even before starting glucocorticoids, given that glucocorticoids can adversely affect an accurate pathologic diagnosis or cause a delay in a definitive diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has an isolated bulky mediastinal mass, an elevated lactate dehydrogenase level, and B symptoms (fever, unintentional weight loss, and night sweats). This presentation is typical of primary mediastinal large B-cell lymphoma. An accurate histologic diagnosis is essential prior to starting therapy, even before starting glucocorticoids, given that glucocorticoids can adversely affect an accurate pathologic diagnosis or cause a delay in a definitive diagnosis.

Key learning point: The first step in the management of a patient who is hemodynamically stable and has symptoms of superior vena cava syndrome and a mediastinal mass is to obtain tissue diagnosis via biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

There is a limited role for irradiating the mediastinal mass emergently if the patient does not have severe respiratory compromise or neurologic changes.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman presents with acute onset of bulky bilateral neck masses. On examination, she is tachycardic and febrile. She has bulky cervical and axillary adenopathy. Initial results from a bedside fine-needle aspiration biopsy reveal atypical cells consistent with high-grade lymphoma.
Selected initial laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
1083
100–190


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
6.5
3.0–4.5


Calcium (mg/dL)
7.8
9.0–10.5


Uric acid (mg/dL)
9.8
1.5–6.0


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.6–1.1


Potassium (mEq/liter)
5.1
3.5–5.0


The patient is started on chemotherapy for her lymphoma and also on allopurinol. In addition, she is given normal saline for aggressive volume expansion that results in urine output of 150 to 200 mL/hour.
After 24 hours, her uric acid level is 13.2 mg/dL, and her serum creatinine level is 1.3 mg/dL. Her physical examination is unchanged with no evidence of volume overload.
Which one of the following treatments should be added to this patient’s regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, a loop diuretic, can be used to increase urine output and facilitate continuation of aggressive volume expansion, but it is typically needed only if the urine output is below target despite aggressive volume expansion or if there is evidence of volume overload.

B) INCORRECT:

Dialysis is indicated in the setting of profound electrolyte disturbances or oliguria.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) from high-grade lymphoma and is at high risk for further cell lysis as she continues chemotherapy.

TLS is the most common emergency associated with hematologic malignancies. The characteristic laboratory abnormalities are hyperuricemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperkalemia. TLS can progress to kidney failure, cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and death from multiorgan system failure.

Morbidity from TLS is reduced by establishing and maintaining a high urine output and reducing the serum uric acid level. The first steps are aggressive intravenous volume expansion with a target urine output of 80 to 100 mL/m2 /hour (150 to 200 mL/hour in most adults) and initiation of allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents uric acid formation. Together, these two interventions usually result in sufficient lowering of serum uric acid to prevent renal complications.

However, in patients at high risk for TLS and in those with active TLS (as in this case), volume expansion and allopurinol alone are insufficient to result in rapid lowering of the serum uric acid level. Rasburicase should also be added, as it can rapidly lower the serum uric acid level to prevent precipitation of urate crystals in the tubules and resulting renal failure.

Key learning point: In patients presenting with established tumor lysis syndrome — characterized by hyperuricemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperkalemia — the best treatment is rasburicase.

D) INCORRECT:

Febuxostat is a newer hypouricemic agent that is indicated in patients for whom rasburicase is not available or is contraindicated (such as patients with glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency).

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary alkalinization increases uric acid solubility and limits the formation of uric acid precipitation. However, it also reduces calcium phosphate solubility and is not recommended for treating tumor lysis syndrome.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a 25-pack-year history of cigarette smoking presents with mild dyspnea, hoarseness, and dysphagia that have progressed during the past 2 weeks.
On examination, her blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation improves from 93% while she is breathing ambient air to 97% when she receives supplemental oxygen (3 liters per minute). She is able to complete full sentences but has to take a break from speaking after a few minutes. She has slight asymmetric facial edema, scattered wheezes, and engorged veins in the neck and on the chest wall.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. CT of the chest shows large, heterogeneous-appearing lymph nodes throughout the mediastinum, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and brachiocephalic vein. Transbronchial biopsy reveals sheets of small, round cells with dark nuclei, typical of small-cell lung cancer.
What is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Surgical bypass grafting of the superior vena cava

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bypass of the superior vena cava (SVC) (which uses an autologous femoral vein or spiral saphenous vein graft from the brachiocephalic vein to the right atrium) is usually reserved for nonmalignant SVC obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Stent placement is useful in patients with severe symptoms, such as respiratory distress, that require urgent intervention.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms (facial swelling, dyspnea, and dysphagia) and imaging findings are consistent with a diagnosis of the superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. Management of SVC syndrome associated with cancer involves both treating the cancer and providing relief from the symptoms of obstruction. In patients with small-cell lung cancer, lymphoma, or germ-cell tumors, clinical response to chemotherapy alone (such as cisplatin and etoposide) is generally rapid.

Key learning point: Patients with superior vena cava syndrome from small-cell lung cancer should be treated with chemotherapy (cisplatin and etoposide) as soon as possible.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiotherapy is unnecessary unless the patient is presenting urgently with a rapidly developing syndrome, airway compromise, or hemodynamic instability.

E) INCORRECT:

Although glucocorticoids reduce tumor burden in lymphomas and thymomas, they are not typically effective in reducing obstruction of the superior vena cava in patients with small-cell lung cancer.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal distention and pain. Her symptoms first started 2 weeks ago and have worsened. She also reports unintended weight loss of 3 kg, ongoing chills, and soaking night sweats.
She was born and raised in Mexico City and immigrated to the United States 3 years ago. She has no recollection of a tuberculosis diagnosis for herself or any close family members.
On physical examination, she is afebrile and in moderate distress, with a heart rate of 118 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 116/73 mm Hg. Her examination is notable for several palpable cervical and inguinal lymph nodes, as well as an enlarged spleen that is tender to palpation. Her abdomen is mildly distended.
A rapid HIV test is positive. The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.1
12.0–16.0


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
1300
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
89,000
150,000–350,000



Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
1860
100–190



Uric acid (mg/dL)
16.3
1.5–6.0



Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.3
0.6–1.1


Potassium (mEq/liter)
6.2
3.5–5.0


Phosphate (mg/dL)
6.8
3.0–4.5


Calcium (mg/dL)
7.1
9.0–10.5


In addition to administering fluids and performing a tissue biopsy, what is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initiation of antiretroviral therapy is important for people with HIV, but the acuity of the current scenario necessitates immediate treatment with fluids and medications to address the uric acid elevation.

B) INCORRECT:

In addition to high-grade lymphoma, which most closely fits the presentation in this case, the differential diagnosis of an elevated LDH level in a person with HIV includes pneumocystis pneumonia, which is treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and tuberculosis, which is treated with at least three antitubercular agents. Other possible diagnoses include toxoplasmosis, histoplasmosis, septic shock, and lung infarction, but the differential diagnosis narrows to high-grade lymphoma and histoplasmosis when the LDH level exceeds 1000 U/liter.

C) INCORRECT:

A bone-marrow biopsy is commonly part of the workup and staging of suspected lymphoma; however, stabilization of the patient is the first step in management.

D) INCORRECT:

In addition to high-grade lymphoma, which most closely fits the presentation in this case, the differential diagnosis of an elevated LDH level in a person with HIV includes pneumocystis pneumonia, which is treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and tuberculosis, which is treated with at least three antitubercular agents. Other possible diagnoses include toxoplasmosis, histoplasmosis, septic shock, and lung infarction, but the differential diagnosis narrows to high-grade lymphoma and histoplasmosis when the LDH level exceeds 1000 U/liter.

E) CORRECT:

Spontaneous tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) occurs most commonly in patients with very aggressive lymphomas (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma) or acute lymphoblastic leukemias. The hallmark of TLS is increased cell turnover marked by elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), uric acid, potassium, and phosphate, as well as decreased serum calcium.

Management of TLS in high-risk patients, such as those with Burkitt lymphoma, includes intravenous fluids and (if the uric acid level is very high) rasburicase to degrade the existing uric acid to a water-soluble renally excreted metabolite. Without treatment, kidney failure will worsen. Rasburicase is highly effective in malignancy-associated hyperuricemia. Of note, rasburicase is contraindicated in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency; patients at increased risk for G6PD deficiency (for example, individuals of African or Mediterranean ancestry) should be screened for G6PD deficiency before starting rasburicase.

Key learning point: Spontaneous tumor lysis syndrome can occur in patients with Burkitt lymphoma and is treated with intravenous fluids and rasburicase.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman with a 4-month history of acute myeloid leukemia was hospitalized to receive chemotherapy with daunorubicin and cytarabine. One day after her chemotherapy was initiated, she developed oliguria. She received a 1-liter bolus of normal saline intravenously, which was continued at 150 mL per hour.
On day 3 of her chemotherapy cycle, she develops dyspnea. Her blood pressure is 110/74 mm Hg, her heart rate is 98 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and her temperature is 37.3°C. On physical examination, her jugular venous pressure is elevated, and she has bibasilar pulmonary crackles and 2+ pitting lower-extremity edema.

On the day of admission, her urinalysis showed no abnormalities. On day 3 of chemotherapy, her urine pH is 5.0 (reference range, 5.0–9.0), and uric acid crystals are present.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient's acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Daunorubicin- or cytarabine-related toxicity is unlikely because these agents do not typically cause acute kidney injury.

B) INCORRECT:

The time course of the decline in renal function in this case is too rapid for acute interstitial nephritis and would not explain the electrolyte abnormalities.

C) INCORRECT:

Prerenal azotemia is unlikely because the patient has been given appropriate fluids with his chemotherapy. In addition, this condition would not explain the electrolyte abnormalities.

D) CORRECT:

Tumor lysis syndrome is an oncologic emergency caused by massive lysis of tumor cells. This process causes the release of large amounts of potassium, phosphate, and nucleic acids into the systemic circulation. Catabolism of the nucleic acids to uric acid leads to hyperuricemia. The marked increase in excretion of uric acid, which is poorly soluble in a low urine pH, leads to the precipitation of uric acid in the renal tubules and acute kidney injury. Hyperphosphatemia with calcium phosphate deposition in the renal tubules can also cause kidney injury. Tumor lysis syndrome most often occurs after cytotoxic therapy is initiated in patients with high-grade lymphomas or leukemia. It can also develop spontaneously with a large tumor burden.

Key learning point: In a patient with acute myeloid leukemia, the most likely reason for the development of acute kidney injury associated with hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, and hyperphosphatemia 3 days after initiating chemotherapy with daunorubicin and cytarabine with appropriate fluids is tumor lysis syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Daunorubicin- or cytarabine-related toxicity is unlikely because these agents do not typically cause acute kidney injury.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman is hospitalized for induction chemotherapy to treat newly diagnosed acute myelogenous leukemia. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. On her third hospital day, she develops muscle spasms, dyspnea, and worsening lower-extremity edema but no fever.
Her current blood pressure is 159/70 mm Hg. When the blood pressure cuff was inflated, she developed a severe muscle spasm in the ipsilateral hand. She is in mild respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. Crackles are audible throughout both lungs. Her jugular veins are distended, and her heart rhythm is regular at a rate of 112 beats per minute. She has 2+ symmetric lower-extremity pitting edema.
Her serum creatinine level has increased from 0.9 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1) one week ago to 3.7 mg/dL today. Her 24-hour urine output is <300 mL despite aggressive volume expansion and a trial of intravenous furosemide.

In addition to consideration of urgent hemodialysis, which one of the following treatments is indicated for this patient?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol and febuxostat inhibit xanthine oxidase and limit uric acid formation, but they do not metabolize previously generated uric acid and thus will not result in rapid lowering of the serum uric acid level, particularly in a patient who is already oliguric. Rasburicase is the preferred prophylactic agent in patients at high risk for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) — and it is the preferred treatment for those with established TLS who require rapid lowering of uric acid or have renal dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide produces an alkaline diuresis and can precipitate calcium-phosphate stone formation.

C) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol and febuxostat inhibit xanthine oxidase and limit uric acid formation, but they do not metabolize previously generated uric acid and thus will not result in rapid lowering of the serum uric acid level, particularly in a patient who is already oliguric. Rasburicase is the preferred prophylactic agent in patients at high risk for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) — and it is the preferred treatment for those with established TLS who require rapid lowering of uric acid or have renal dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate is a controversial approach that increases the solubility of uric acid but can lead to calcium-phosphate deposition in the kidney and other organs. It is not recommended if rasburicase is available.

E) CORRECT:

Uric acid nephropathy secondary to tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is a common cause of kidney injury in patients with large tumor burdens (e.g., high-grade lymphomas and acute leukemias).

TLS can occur when there is massive cell lysis, and large amounts of phosphate, potassium, and nucleic acids are released into the circulation. Nucleic acids are metabolized into uric acid, which can lead to acute kidney injury. The serum calcium level may be very low because of chelation by phosphate anions released by tumor cells.

Aggressive volume expansion, which improves renal perfusion and minimizes uric acid and calcium phosphate precipitation in the tubules, is the key treatment modality to prevent TLS. In addition, lowering the uric acid level can reduce the risk for kidney damage. In patients such as this one, with established hyperuricemia, rasburicase is the recommended hypouricemic agent.

Rasburicase, a recombinant urate-oxidase enzyme, is absent in humans and rapidly metabolizes uric acid into carbon dioxide, hydrogen peroxide, and allantoin, which are more soluble than uric acid. Because rasburicase leads to hydrogen-peroxide formation, patients receiving this medication are at risk for developing methemoglobinemia or hemolytic anemia, especially if they have glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Patients who are at high risk for G6PD deficiency, specifically those of African or Mediterranean ancestry, should be tested for G6PD deficiency before initiation of rasburicase.

Key learning point: In a patient with hyperuricemia from tumor lysis syndrome, the serum uric acid level can be lowered most rapidly with rasburicase.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with facial swelling. He reports that he has had a mild cough for the past 3 weeks, along with four to five separate instances of fever, reaching a maximum temperature of 38.9°C. He has also had swollen lymph nodes in his neck for the past 2 weeks. Yesterday, he developed gradual swelling of the skin under both eyes, followed by worsening swelling of the face; the swelling seems worse in the morning. He has had no nasal congestion, runny nose, or sore throat. He is eating and drinking well and has had normal urine output. He takes no medications and has no known allergies.
On physical examination, he is awake and interactive but appears tired. He has a temperature of 38.6°C, a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 110/69 mm Hg. His oxygen saturation is 97% while he is supine and breathing ambient air. He has moderate periorbital swelling bilaterally, as well as slight swelling of the entire face. He has moderate jugular venous distention bilaterally. He has a dry cough but is breathing comfortably without retractions. Breath sounds are slightly diminished over the posterior right lung fields. His cardiac, abdominal, musculoskeletal, and neurologic examinations are unremarkable. He has diffuse cervical, supraclavicular, and axillary lymphadenopathy.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals significant mediastinal widening and hilar fullness.
The patient is placed in an upright position, laboratory tests are ordered, and continuous cardiopulmonary monitoring is initiated.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain a chest CT with contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Facial swelling, cough, and mediastinal widening on chest radiograph are all signs of superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. SVC syndrome occurs when compression of the venous and airway structures in the anterior mediastinum leads to venous congestion and, at advanced stages, airway compromise. The most likely etiology is a mediastinal mass. In this case, the patient has lymphadenopathy, intermittent fevers, fatigue, and hilar fullness on chest radiograph, all of which suggest an oncologic process. Although the exact diagnosis is not necessary for immediate management, it is likely this patient has either T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma or Hodgkin lymphoma.

Early recognition of SVC syndrome is critical to identify patients at high risk for rapid respiratory decline and failure. In its earliest stages, SVC syndrome manifests with facial and neck swelling as well as venous distention. In later stages, it manifests as overt SVC obstruction with cyanosis, dyspnea, stridor, or even respiratory arrest.

This patient has evidence of SVC syndrome but is currently stable without respiratory distress, stridor, or cyanosis. Contrast-enhanced chest CT should be obtained as early as possible to safely and efficiently characterize the mass and to evaluate for evidence of airway edema. All patients with signs of SVC syndrome or a mediastinal mass should have their supine oxygen saturation checked to assess whether they will be able to tolerate the scan and should also be placed on continuous cardiopulmonary monitoring in order to rapidly detect respiratory decline.

This patient may require an echocardiogram and electrocardiogram, but these tests should not be prioritized over imaging and stabilization.

Key learning point: The first clinical findings of superior vena cava syndrome include facial or neck swelling.

B) INCORRECT:

Although glucocorticoids (e.g., dexamethasone) might be used in a patient with significant airway edema, they can interfere with tissue diagnosis and should not be used, if possible, in patients (such as this one) who are stable without signs of imminent decline.

C) INCORRECT:

Intubation is not yet necessary for this patient, given that he does not currently show signs of respiratory failure. However, the medical team should be prepared to rapidly intubate if he does decline.

D) INCORRECT:

Although patients with suspected SVC syndrome require as calming an environment as possible, a benzodiazepine (e.g., lorazepam) is not appropriate given the patient’s high risk for respiratory compromise.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient requires tissue diagnosis, bronchoscopy is not indicated. Anesthesia, which would be needed for bronchoscopy, should be avoided whenever possible in patients with mediastinal masses, given the risk for reduced venous return and cardiorespiratory compromise. A peripheral node or bone marrow biopsy is typically performed, using local anesthesia if possible, in order to avoid general anesthesia.

Intravenous furosemide is added to the patient’s regimen and titrated to a goal urine output of 200 mL per hour.
Which one of the following interventions should be initiated at this time?

choices.text: Change the normal saline to a sodium bicarbonate infusion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium supplementation in the setting of TLS should be reserved for patients with symptomatic hypocalcemia and should be provided in the smallest dose required to address symptoms because the addition of calcium may promote calcium phosphate precipitation. This patient does not have symptoms, so the addition of calcium is not advised.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinary alkalinization via infusion of intravenous sodium bicarbonate can increase uric acid solubility and renal excretion, thus limiting uric acid precipitation in the kidneys. However, alkali therapy also reduces calcium phosphate solubility and can reduce ionized calcium. This strategy is less effective when there is established acute kidney injury and is no longer recommended for treating TLS now that rasburicase is available.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral phosphate binders are used in patients with chronic kidney disease and are not indicated for acute hyperphosphatemia, as they have not been proven to be efficacious in this setting. Although they are still occasionally prescribed for this purpose, phosphate excretion with volume expansion is more likely to improve hyperphosphatemia and should therefore be initiated first.

D) INCORRECT:

Changing this patient’s allopurinol dosing from once daily to divided doses every 8 hours will not adequately lower her serum uric acid concentration at this time. Allopurinol is often dosed every 8 hours for prevention, with a maximum dose of 800 mg daily, but the dose should be reduced in the setting of renal dysfunction. Moreover, allopurinol increases the risk of crystalline xanthine deposits, which could increase the risk of renal failure.

E) CORRECT:

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is caused by release of the contents of malignant cells into the bloodstream, resulting in electrolyte abnormalities, which may include hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia.

Strategies for preventing and monitoring TLS vary depending on individual risk for TLS. Risk varies depending on the tumor being treated: smaller solid cancers and indolent lymphomas are associated with the lowest risk, and aggressive leukemias and cancers with large tumor burdens are associated with the highest risk. Patients with acute lymphocytic leukemia and a leukocyte count >50,000 cells per mm3 (as in this case) are in the highest risk category, and aggressive efforts at prevention would be advised.

When the risk of TLS is low, volume expansion during chemotherapy and close laboratory monitoring is typically an adequate management strategy. Allopurinol (a hypoxanthine analogue that blocks the metabolism of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid) is also commonly added to prevent hyperuricemia and resultant renal injury.

In high-risk patients, particularly those who have renal dysfunction or uric acid levels >8 mg/dL before initiating chemotherapy, rasburicase is preferred. Rasburicase is a recombinant urate oxidase (uricase) that catalyzes the oxidation of uric acid to the more soluble allantoin. This agent leads to a rapid decrease in the serum uric acid level and is a better option than allopurinol for preventing renal failure in patients at high risk.

Of note, rasburicase is not entirely benign; it can, on rare occasions, cause hypersensitivity reactions and methemoglobinemia. In addition, it should not be given to patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency because it can cause severe hemolysis.

Choosing Appropriate Management in This Case

Given that this patient has an aggressive leukemia and her uric acid level was approaching 8 mg/dL at presentation, she was at high risk for TLS. Rasburicase could have reasonably been started at the same time as her cancer treatment to prevent TLS. Unfortunately, she has now developed this condition despite preventive measures with allopurinol and volume expansion.

The treatment of TLS includes rasburicase, aggressive volume expansion with normal saline, and, if needed, a loop diuretic to achieve a target urine output of 80 to 100 mL/m2 /hour (around 150–200 mL/hour for most adults). Electrolyte levels should be closely monitored and managed as appropriate. In rare cases, hemodialysis may be indicated in patients with TLS to help manage volume overload or hyperkalemia that is resistant to other interventions.

Key learning point: Patients who are at high risk for tumor lysis syndrome or who have uric acid levels >8 mg/dL despite aggressive volume expansion are considered candidates for treatment with rasburicase.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents, who report that he has had daily fevers for the past 10 days, up to 39.4°C on axillary readings. At the onset of the fevers, he had a cough and rhinorrhea, but these symptoms have resolved. He is usually very active and playful but has had increasing fatigue and now spends most of the day napping. He has had no vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, or other localizing symptoms.
On examination, he has a temperature of 38.9°C, a heart rate of 172 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 45 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/54 mm Hg. He is pale and appears tired but nontoxic. Both lungs are clear to auscultation. He has a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. The abdomen is soft and nontender, the liver edge is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin, and the spleen tip is palpable. There is nontender cervical lymphadenopathy, with all nodes <1.5 cm in diameter, and scattered petechiae and bruises in various stages of healing on both lower extremities.
Laboratory results are as follows:

Leukocytes (per mm3)

6000–17,000

A peripheral blood smear is obtained (figure).
A blood culture is obtained, and intravenous fluids and antibiotics are started.
Which one of the following medications should be administered to this patient next?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dexamethasone may be an appropriate part of a chemotherapy regimen used to treat acute leukemia but should not be initiated until a complete workup has been done, including staging with lumbar puncture and bone-marrow biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

A blood transfusion may be indicated for this patient if he becomes more symptomatic from his anemia, but it is not necessary for acute management, given his current hemoglobin concentration >7.0 g/dL. He should be monitored closely, however, given his elevated heart rate.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is commonly used to treat immune thrombocytopenia, which may manifest with petechiae. This patient has neutropenia and anemia in addition to thrombocytopenia, making immune thrombocytopenia an unlikely diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical and laboratory findings, including peripheral blasts seen on the smear, are concerning for acute leukemia and tumor lysis syndrome.

Acute leukemia is the most common cancer in children and manifests with nonspecific symptoms, including hepatosplenomegaly, pallor, fever, and easy bruising. Anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia are classic laboratory findings in acute leukemia and should prompt the clinician to obtain a peripheral smear to look for blasts or atypical young leukocytes. In addition, the clinician should obtain a complete blood count and check electrolytes, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and uric acid levels to investigate for tumor lysis syndrome, a series of metabolic derangements that can occur with high rates of cell turnover.

Tumor lysis syndrome is associated with high levels of LDH and uric acid as well as hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia. It typically occurs after cancer treatment has already been initiated, but in some cases (such as this one), the electrolyte abnormalities are present at the time of cancer diagnosis. Malignancies with more friable cells, such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia, more often manifest with tumor lysis syndrome at the time of diagnosis. Intravenous fluids are a mainstay of management in newly diagnosed malignancies with tumor lysis, but it is important to realize that the lysis of friable cells often increases with fluid administration and therefore patients require frequent monitoring.

Prophylactic regimens to prevent kidney damage from high levels of uric acid include aggressive hydration (without potassium) and either rasburicase, which enhances the clearance of uric acid, or allopurinol, which limits the production of uric acid. This patient’s uric acid level is already well above the upper limit of normal, so one of these two medications should be started with chemotherapy to limit any further uricemia due to tumor lysis. Rasburicase is recombinant urate oxidase, which degrades the uric acid, whereas allopurinol competitively inhibits xanthine oxidase, preventing the production of uric acid. Rasburicase can be considered if uric acid levels are already elevated before the initiation of chemotherapy or fluids.

Key learning point: For a patient with signs and symptoms that suggest acute leukemia and hyperuricemia, initial management should include rasburicase or allopurinol.

E) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is used in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia but is not part of induction or initial management.
